I'm not going to put that in an irrelevant article
They should focus in fixing the native crash bugs
I was joking
I ain't writing an article about that hah
I've got 1 native crash bug so far
It's my only crash
But it's on an older version
I only got 'em back in the day when I didn't cancel failed transactions.
Realm didn't like random open transactions here and there
cancelling failed transactions is for quitters
And people who don't like native crashes, apparently :p
Anyways, `realm.executeTransaction()` makes that easy
You can easily store any RealmList of primitives as a single String field
And saves you the pain of managing linked RealmObjects
(as in, deleting them)
Great, do you have a suggestion on how to solve it?

you’re executing the code? :stuck_out_tongue:
I subscribed to an observable and used the debounce
if I dont subscribe and I type then when I resubscribe all the values I typed are queued up
maybe I was doing something funky
ahhh
becuase the debounce operates on the computation thread by default
and I was using it on the mainthread as i was observing character
thats maybe why
<@U3E2EEX38|name_gone> uploaded a file: <https://androidchat.slack.com/files/name_gone/F3RN9QY2X/-.java|Untitled>

file.name: -.java
file.title: Untitled
file.preview_highlight:
public final Observable<T> debounce(long timeout, TimeUnit unit) {
    return debounce(timeout, unit, Schedulers.computation());
}

text:
As a result, the subscriber's callbacks are invoked on that same computation scheduler, since nothing is explicitly instructing otherwise.

Now, attempting to update a view (that's what's happening in onNext()) from any other thread than the main/ui thread, is a mistake and it will lead to undetermined results.

    .subscribe(...);

    .debounce(300, TimeUnit.MILLISECONDS)
    .observeOn(AndroidSchedulers.mainThread())
    .subscribe(...);

you need to `.observeOn( AndroidSchedulers.mainThread())`  and `subscribeOn(<http://Schedulers.io|Schedulers.io>())` in `searchQuerySubscription`

<@U3RJ74KQA> consider using GSON or LoganSquare or another parser that does things automatically and just use this

```
-----------------------------------com.example.Example.java-----------------------------------

package com.example;

import com.google.gson.annotations.Expose;
import com.google.gson.annotations.SerializedName;

public class Example {

@SerializedName("1")
@Expose
private String _1;

public String get1() {
return _1;
}

public void set1(String _1) {
this._1 = _1;
}

}
```

<@U0A1BE7KQ> consider separation of packages by feature instead of `activities` `fragments` `models` `network` etc. because you'll get lost whenever you're looking for something specific related to a specific functionality in your app.

personally I like to do `data / domain / presentation / utils`, and then separate the `presentation` package by features so that my custom views and adapters and activities aren't in 4 different packages
this is just an advice
if you separate things by "what they are", you'll eventually get lost when looking for something

And be careful when passing context into an object -> <https://github.com/lawloretienne/MovieHub/blob/master/app/src/main/java/com/etiennelawlor/moviehub/network/interceptors/AuthorizedNetworkInterceptor.java>

attachments.title: lawloretienne/MovieHub
attachments.text: MovieHub - Showcases popular movies, tv shows, and people from The Movie Database

you can get it with calling context.getApplicationContext()
